comment.author: 32428096@N05
comment._content:
A real moment in time. 

The railway bridge has not changed much in 100+ years!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: It really hasn't! If any of you have pics of the ads on the bridge over the years, we'd love to see them. Personal favourite was "Butty Bridge" - ad for rashers and sausages!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: Fantastic detail a pleasure to view.

comment.author: 56225952@N06
comment._content: This is perfect for an illustrated edition of Ulysses (as is the view from the top of Nelson's Pillar). A fabulous photograph.

comment.author: 45155974@N02
comment._content: What a fabulous photo! And all the more interesting to me because my grandmother, Elizabeth Timmons, was born at Britain Street (now Parnell Street) in 1880, so this sight would probably have been very common to her.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/45155974@N02] And still one of the most bustling corners in Dublin... If our dating of this photo is correct, your grandmother would have been 17 when this was taken.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 28791102@N08
comment._content: It strikes me that this must have been shot with a shutter speed around 1/60 sec which would have been fast given the technology of the time. Early urban landscapes seem devoid of people only because exposures were long and people and vehicles move through the scene without being recorded.
